Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on "Surface, Interface, and Coating Materials" Symposium, 256th American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meeting; Boston, Massachusetts; 19-23 August 2018

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Coatings of surfaces is a fundamental materials process which impacts all areas of technology and is critical to many commercial products and manufacturing processes in industry, including coating, construction, chemical, cosmetic and drug formulation. As such it is key to all aspects of our national prosperity and welfare. Surface and interface of materials also play important roles in many research areas and is one of the most active cross-disciplinary topics. This grant supports a symposium on the topic of "Surface, Interface, and Coating Materials" at the 256th American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meeting. This symposium covers the recent advances in chemistry, physics and engineering of polymeric materials directly related to surface, interface and coating applications. The symposium is truly interdisciplinary, encouraging crosstalk and collaborations among different fields. Research discussed here will set the tone for future directions in surface and interface research, together with the next generation coating materials for industrial applications. It will also provide a multidisciplinary platform for scientists, including graduate students, postdocs and junior faculties, from both academia and industry to exchange information from different areas, and identify the emerging trends in fundamental research based on the needs of industry.

This symposium will focus on the development of new chemistry and materials that enables tailoring physicochemical properties of surface and interface for diverse applications. Particular attention will be given to functionalized surfaces, such as super-hydrophobic surface, anti-fouling surface, anti-corrosion surface and smart coating materials. The symposium will also include the new analytical tools developed to characterize novel surface and interface, as well as the theories and computer simulations developed to help comprehensively understand the interfacial phenomena. The symposium is divided into three specific focus areas: (1) new chemical synthesis, physics and engineering related to surfaces; (2) study of interface in biomaterials and composite materials; (3) coating materials research and applications. The objectives are: (1) to highlight recent advances in the design, synthesis and characterization of surface and interface; (2) to translation of technologies generated in lab to industrial applications; (3) to promote dialogues and to exchange ideas among scientists and researchers across different disciplines, from both industry and academia; and (4) to provide opportunities for both senior and young investigators to present their most updated research results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported a symposium on the topic of “Surface, Interface, and Coating Materials” at 256th American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meeting in Boston. This symposium comprehensively reviewed the recent advances in chemistry, physics and engineering of polymeric materials that are related to surface, interface and coating applications. It extensively presented the challenges faced in the field and talked about the new ideas and potential solutions. The symposium was truly interdisciplinary and encouraged the crosstalk and collaborations among different fields. Surface and interface of materials play important roles in many research areas and is one of the most active cross-disciplinary topics. On the other hand, surface and interface are also critical to many commercial products and manufacturing processes in industry, including coating, construction chemical, cosmetic and drug formulation. Research discussed here sets the tone for future directions in surface and interface research, together with the next generation coating materials for industrial applications. It also provided a multidisciplinary platform for scientists, including graduate students, postdocs and junior faculties, from both academia and industry to receive information from different areas, and quickly figure out the trend in fundamental research and the demand from industrial application. All the presentation title and abstracts were posted on the ACS website.

This symposium focused on the development of new chemistry and materials that enables tailoring physicochemical properties of surface and interface for diverse applications. Particular attention was given to functionalized surfaces, such as super-hydrophobic surface, anti-fouling surface, anti-corrosion surface and smart coating materials. The symposium also included the new analytical tools developed to characterize novel surface and interface, as well as the theories and computer simulations developed to help comprehensively understand the interfacial phenomena. The symposium was divided into three specific focus areas: (1) new chemical synthesis, physics and engineering related to surfaces; (2) study of interface in biomaterials and composite materials; (3) coating materials research and applications. The following objectives were successfully achieved: (1) to highlight recent advances in the design, synthesis and characterization of surface and interface; (2) to translation of technologies generated in lab to industrial applications; (3) to promote dialogues and to exchange ideas among scientists and researchers across different disciplines, from both industry and academia; and (4) to provide opportunities for both senior and young investigators to present their most updated research results.

The symposium was very well participated! Through ACS abstract submission system, the symposium received 90 submissions, among which 21 were invited talks. Total number of U.S. participants is 69, while 21 presenters were from Canada, China, Germany, Turkey, Sweden, South Korea and India. The organizers examined the abstracts and discussed about the selection. All abstracts were accepted, with 78 abstracts scheduled for oral presentation and the rest for poster presentation. The selection was based on the quality of the abstract. An announcement of the NSF travel award was sent out to all the invited speakers. 8 speakers applied and received the award. All the awardees attended and presented at the symposium. All the awardees are junior researchers in the field, including graduate students, postdocs and assistant professors. One awardee is from industry, who is also an African American.

Here is a rough estimation of the attendance based on the headcount by the presider of the session. After each oral presentation, the audience was given the opportunity to ask questions.

8/20 morning – 80; afternoon – 60
8/21 morning – 70; afternoon – 70
8/21 morning – 70; afternoon – 50
8/21 morning – 50;

Overall, the symposium was very well received and attended. It was one of the most popular sessions among symposiums in the PMSE division. The program hosted many prestigious researchers in the field, including professors from top universities and institutes such as Harvard, MIT, Northwestern, UC-Berkley, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, University of Michigan, University of Pennsylvania, Cornell University, University of Toronto, Queen’s University, University of Washington, RWTH Aachen University, North Carolina State University, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Sandia National Lab, Naval Research Laboratory, Iowa State University, Wayne State University and University of Binghamton. The talks were very well attended and received.

The program also hosted many speakers and audiences from industry, including Dow Chemical, PPG, Antonomic Materials, Adaptive Surface Technologies, BASF and ExxonMobil. A unique session was hosted with focus on industry R&D research in the coating field. Researchers from PPG, Dow, BASF and many other companies were present in the session.
